abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.para: This document describes how to install and use pluginbox, the PLUGIN-Based queue engine for Kannel.

highlights.para: Pluginbox is a special Kannel box that sits between bearerbox and smsbox and uses a database queue to store and forward messages.

sect1.title: Overview
sect1.para: Pluginbox behaves similar to other Kannel boxes and share a compatible configuration file format and command line options.
It works between bearerbox and smsbox, intercept all messages and uses user defined plugins to intercept and process messages.

listitem.para: Modular architecture: Easily integrates into Kannel infrastructure.
Compatible configuration file format and command line arguments.

sect1.title: Requirements
sect1.para: pluginbox is being developed on Linux and OSX systems, and should be fairly easy to export to other Unix-like systems. However, we don't yet support other platforms, due to lack of time, although it should be working without major problems on Windows (through Cygwin), Mac OSX, Solaris and FreeBSD.

pluginbox requires the following software environment:
Kannel libraries (gwlib) installed.
C compiler and libraries for ANSI C, with normal Unix extensions such as BSD sockets and related tools. (GNU's GCC tool-chain is recommended)
GNU Make.
An implementation of POSIX threads ( pthread.h ).
DocBook processing tools: DocBook style-sheets, jade, jadetex, etc; see README , section `Documentation', for more information (pre-formatted versions of the documentation are available, and you can compile Pluginbox itself even without the documentation tools).
GNU autoconf

chapter.title: Installing pluginbox
chapter.para: This chapter explains how to build and install pluginbox from source or from a binary package. The goal of this chapter is to get the module compiled and all the files in the correct places; the next chapter will explain how to configure it.

note.para: If you are upgrading from a previous version, please look at for any important information.

sect1.title: Getting the source code
sect1.para: The source code to Pluginbox is available for download at https://github.com/donald-jackson/kannel-pluginbox. It is available in various formats and you can choose to download either the latest release version or the daily snapshot of the development source tree for the next release version, depending on whether you want to use Pluginbox for production use or to participate in the development.

sect1.title: Finding the documentation
sect1.para:
The documentation for Pluginbox consists of two parts:
User's Guide , i.e., the one you're reading at the moment.
The README and various other text files in the source tree.
You can also find general information on Kannel's website and information about existing problems at our bugtracker .

We intend to cover everything you need to install and use Pluginbox is in User's Guide , but the guide is still incomplete in this respect. The README is not supposed to be very important, nor contain much information. Instead, it will just point at the other documentation.

sect1.title: Compiling pluginbox
sect1.para:
If you are using Pluginbox on a supported platform, or one that is similar enough to one, compiling Pluginbox should be trivial. After you have unpacked the source package of your choose, or after you have checked out the source code from CVS, enter the following commands:
./bootstrap ./configure make
The bootstrap script uses autoconf to generate the files needed to build the module. The configure script investigates various things on your computer for the Pluginbox compilation needs, and writes out the Makefile used to compile the module. make then runs the commands to actually compile it.

If either command writes out an error message and stops before it finishes its job, you have a problem, and you either need to fix it yourself, if you can, or report the problem to the Kannel project. See for details.

For detailed instruction on using the configuration script, see file INSTALL . That file is a generic documentation for configure . Pluginbox defines a few additional options:
--with-kannel-dir= DIR Where to look for Kannel Gateway libs and header files DIR points to the Kannel installation directory. Defaults to /usr/local
--disable-docs (default is --enable-docs) Use this option if you don't have DocBook installed and/or you want to save some time and CPU cycles. Pre-generated documentation is available on Kannel's site. Default behavior is to build documentation, b.e., converting the User Guide from the DocBook markup language to PostScript and HTML if DocBook is available.
--enable-drafts (default is --disable-drafts) When building documentation, include the sections marked as draft .

You may need to add compilations flags to configure:
CFLAGS='-pthread' ./configure
The above, for instance, seems to be required on FreeBSD. If you want to develop Pluginbox, you probably want to add CFLAGS that make your compiler use warning messages. For example, for GCC:
CFLAGS='-Wall -O2 -g' ./configure
(You may, at your preference, use even stricter checking options.)

sect1.title: Installing Pluginbox
sect1.para:
After you have compiled Kannel, you need to install the pluginbox binary in a suitable place. This is most easily done by using make again:
make bindir=/path/to/directory install
Replace /path/to/directory with the pathname of the actual directory where the programs should be installed. This install the pluginbox binary:
gw/pluginbox

chapter.title: Using pluginbox
chapter.para: This chapter explains how to configure and run Pluginbox and also how to tell if it's running from Kannel's HTTP interface.
There is only one configuration file for Pluginbox, and that file commands all aspects of its execution.

sect1.title: Configuring Pluginbox
sect1.para: The configuration file can be divided into two parts: pluginbox configuration and database connection.
Details of each part are in appropriate sections later on this documentation.

sect2.title: Configuration file syntax
sect2.para: The syntax used for the configuration file is the same used in Kannel. Skip this section if you are already familiar with it. Otherwise, keep on reading:

A configuration file consists of groups of configuration variables. Groups are separated by empty lines, and each variable is defined on its own line. Each group in Pluginbox configuration is distinguished with a group variable. Comments are lines that begin with a number sign ( # ) and are ignored (they don't, for example, separate groups of variables).

A variable definition line has the name of the variable, and equals sign ( = ) and the value of the variable. The name of the variable can contain any characters except whitespace and equals. The value of the variable is a string, with or without quotation marks (
) around it. Quotation marks are needed if the variable needs to begin or end with whitespace or contain special characters. Normal C escape character syntax works inside quotation marks.

Perhaps an example will make things easier to comprehend:
01 # Pluginbox configuration 02 group = pluginbox 03 log-level = 0 04 log-file = "/var/log/kannel/kannel-pluginbox.log" 05 bearerbox-host = localhost 06 bearerbox-port = 13001 07 smsbox-port = 13005 08 smsbox-port-ssl = false
09 group=pluginbox-plugin 10 path=/opt/kannel/sbin/plugins/pluginbox_example.so 11 init="pluginbox_example_init" 12 priority=1
13 group=pluginbox-plugin 14 path=/opt/kannel/sbin/plugins/pluginbox_example.so 15 init="pluginbox_example_init" 16 priority=2
The above snipped shows a Pluginbox configuration which has two instances of the example plugin.
Lines 1 and 14 are comment lines. Line 13 separates the two groups. The remaining lines define variables. The group type is defined by the group variable value.
The various variables that are understood in each type of configuration group are explained below.

Some variable values are marked as 'bool'. The value for variable can be like true, false, yes, no, on, off, 0 or 1. Other values are treated as 'true' while if the variable is not present at all, it is treated as being 'false'.

sect2.title: Inclusion of configuration files
sect2.para: A configuration file may contain a special directive called include to include other file or a directory with files to the configuration processing.
This allows to segment the specific configuration groups required for several services and boxes to different files and hence to have more control in larger setups.

Here is an example that illustrates the include statement :
group = pluginbox ... log-file = "/var/log/kannel/kannel-pluginbox.log" log-level = 0 include = "plugins.conf"
Above is the main pluginbox.conf configuration file that includes the following plugins.conf file with all required directives for the plugin setup.
group=pluginbox-plugin path=/opt/kannel/sbin/plugins/pluginbox_example.so init="pluginbox_example_init" priority=2 args=plugin-config.conf
The above include statement may be defined at any point in the configuration file and at any inclusion depth. Hence you can cascade numerous inclusions if necessary.

At process start time inclusion of configuration files breaks if either the included file can not be opened and processed or the included file has been processed already in the stack and a recursive cycling has been detected.

sect2.title: Pluginbox configuration
sect2.para: The configuration file MUST always include an 'pluginbox' group for general configuration. This group should be the first group in the configuration file.

As its simplest form, 'pluginbox' group looks like this:
group = pluginbox bearerbox-port = 13001 smsbox-port = 13005
Naturally this is usually not sufficient for any real use. Thus, one or more of the optional configuration variables are used. In following list (as in any other similar lists), all mandatory variables are marked with (m), while conditionally mandatory (variables which must be set in certain cases) are marked with (c) .

row.entry: Variable
Value
Description
This is a mandatory variable

tbody.entry: This is the host where bearerbox is running.

row.entry: port-number
This is the port number used to connect to bearerbox.
port-number
This is the port number to which the smsboxes, if any, connect. This can be anything you want. Must be set if you want to handle any SMS traffic.
bool

If set to true, the smsbox connection module will be SSL-enabled. Your smsboxes will have to connect using SSL to pluginbox then. This is used to secure communication between pluginbox and smsboxes in case they are in separate networks operated and the TCP communication is not secured on a lower network layer. Defaults to "no".
filename
A file in which to write a log. This in addition to stdout and any log file defined in command line.
number 0..5
Minimum level of log-file events logged. 0 is for 'debug', 1 'info', 2 'warning, 3 'error' and 4 'panic' (see Command Line Options)

sect2.para:
A sample more complex 'pluginbox' group could be something like this:
group = pluginbox bearerbox-host = localhost bearerbox-port = 13001 smsbox-port = 13005 smsbox-port-ssl = false log-file = "/var/log/kannel/kannel-pluginbox.log" log-level = 0 #ssl-client-certkey-file = "" #ssl-server-cert-file = "" #ssl-server-key-file = "" #ssl-trusted-ca-file = ""

sect1.title: The Plugin groups
sect1.para: pluginbox will execute plugins in order of priority (highest to lowest)
The process of configuring a plugin is simple: You need to create a pluginbox-plugin section which contains the plugin dynamic library file (.so or .dylib) and specifies an init function.

sect2.title: pluginbox-plugin configuration
sect2.para: Definition of a plugin to execute

row.entry: Variable
Value
Description
This is a mandatory variable.
This is the full path to the .so file to load.
This is the name of the init function to initialize this plugin. This function will hook in other functions as needed.
The execution priority of the plugin (higher numbers get executed first)
Arguments to pass to the plugin for initialization or other purposes.

sect2.para: Example configuration:
sect2.programlisting: group = myplugin-connection id = my-pluginbox host = localhost username = foo password = bar database = kannel max-connections = 1

sect1.title: Running Pluginbox
sect1.para: You need to start pluginbox after starting the bearerbox, otherwise it won't have a port open to connect to. The preferred way to do this is to include pluginbox into your Kannel's startup script.

sect2.title: Starting the box
sect2.para:
If you want to start it from command line (for testing, for example), give the following command:
/path/to/pluginbox -v 1 [config-file]
The -v 1 sets the logging level to INFO. This way, you won't see a large amount of debugging output (the default is DEBUG). Full explanation of Pluginbox command line arguments is below.

[config-file] is the name of the configuration file you are using with Pluginbox. The basic distribution packet comes with a sample configuration file you can use with some minor tweakings (check on the /examples folder. Feel free to edit the file to suit your needs.
Of course you need to have the bearerbox running before starting the box. Without the bearer box, pluginbox won't even start.

sect2.title: Command line options
sect2.para: Pluginbox accept certain command line options and arguments when they are launched. These arguments are:

row.entry: Set verbosity level for stdout (screen) logging. Default is 0, which means 'debug'. 1 is 'info, 2 'warning', 3 'error' and 4 'panic'
Set debug-places for 'debug' level output.
Log to file named file-name, too. Does not overrun or affect any log-file defined in configuration file.
Set verbosity level for that extra log-file (default 0, which means 'debug'). Does not affect verbosity level of the log-file defined in configuration file, not verbosity level of the stdout output.
Only try to open HTTP sendsms interface; if it fails, only warn about that, do not exit. (smsbox only)
Dump all known config groups and config keys to stdout and exit.
Change process user-id to the given.
Write process PID to the given file.

Start process as daemon (detached from a current shell session). Note: Process will change CWD (Current working directory) to /, therefore you should ensure that all paths to binary/config/config-includes are absolute instead of relative.
Start watcher process. This process watch a child process and if child process crashed will restart them automatically.

Execute a given shell script or binary when child process crash detected. This option is usable only with --parachute/-P. Script will be executed with 2 arguments: scriptname 'processname' 'respawn-count'.

chapter.title: Getting help and reporting bugs
chapter.para: This chapter explains where to find help with problems related to the gateway, and the preferred procedure for reporting bugs and sending corrections to them.

The Kannel development mailing list is devel@kannel.org. To subscribe, send mail to devel-subscribe@kannel.org. This is currently the best location for asking help and reporting bugs. Please include configuration file and version number.

appendix.title: Upgrading notes
appendix.para: This appendix includes pertinent information about required changes on upgrades.
As a general rule, always check the ChangeLog file before upgrading, because it may contain important information worth knowing before making any changes.

sect1.title: Upgrading from different pluginbox versions
sect1.para: Pluginbox is a simple module that usually upgrades easily and without requiring any other changes.
